"The Overview Effect. <[silence]> A profound shift in perspective.<[silence]>
The term combines 'overview'—a broad, comprehensive view—and 'effect,' the result of that view.<[silence]> It describes the cognitive and emotional transformation astronauts undergo when they see Earth from space.<[silence]> This phenomenon was first noted by psychologist Frank White in 1987, after observing common experiences among astronauts.<[silence]>

Imagine floating above our planet, seeing its fragile beauty, and realizing we're all connected.<[silence]> This sudden, global perspective can be overwhelming, leading to feelings of awe, unity, and responsibility.<[silence]> Astronauts often report a newfound appreciation for Earth's ecosystems and a desire to protect them.<[silence]> One famous example is Apollo 14's Edgar Mitchell, who co-founded the Institute of Noetic Sciences to study such experiences.<[silence]>

The Overview Effect isn't limited to space. Similar transformations occur in high-altitude climbers, deep-sea divers, and even those who view Earth from tall buildings or drones.<[silence]> Each experience offers a new perspective, fostering empathy and connection.<[silence]> Yet, it's not just about seeing the world anew—it's about understanding our place in it.<[silence]>

Three related subjects are the psychological impact of space travel, the role of perspective in environmentalism, and the potential of virtual reality to induce similar experiences on Earth."
